messages.message: Thanks @Hari, will add it to the investigation
@avi please share the link to the bot

https://aihub.instabase.com/hub/apps/57a726db-ef7b-4154-81c1-91202863305b @Sławek Biel

I remember coming across this issue before

It doesn’t look to me like there is something broken here. This kind of mistakes are inherent to how we do things.

When you search the vector store for a thing like “what is the most recent release of AI Hub” every chunk that talks about a release is equally relevant, the text doesn’t contain anything to anchor to like “this is the newest release” so it’s totally possible that a chunk from the first page doesn’t make the cut by a chance.

@Hari A reranking step could work well for cases like this. When looking at multiple chunks it should be easy for the model to see which chunks are more recent and therefore more relevant. But that requires either getting a license and paying Cohere to do it, or trying to train a model on our own.

Makes sense @Sławek Biel. Do you think it would help if we added a label in the release notes doc to indicate `24.34 is the latest release`? I guess a bit of "prompt eng" in the doc is useful too :sweat_smile:

I’m reluctant because it feels like cheating, at the same time I don’t have other suggestions that are easily done. CC @vineeth for ms-lite expertise.

But yes, if there is a way to seamlessly integrate this information it would help with this particular query.

Yeah it is definitely making the "test" easier for our models. But at the same time want to ensure we are able to provide a good response for the docsbot since we expect it'll become more prominent as we feature on the docs site.

@jean do you think we can seamlessly include a tag/note on the release note page to indicate the latest release version? Though humans can easily infer this, it feels like useful information for us too :stuck_out_tongue:
Funnily enough, there is a call to standardize adding machine readable information to websites https://llmstxt.org/ :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:

Yeah, it feels a little like a hack, like this is the kind of thing the model should be able to figure out. But of course, we can add something to be practical and make it work. I think the odd thing to me is that when I’ve tested this query previously, it’s always given me the correct answer.

Okay, I’ve added (latest) to the current release version in the release notes, and that does indeed seem to help with the result. @Balaram, can you please make sure the updated bot is public again? :pleading_face: Thank you! cc @avi
